description:
Supreme Ruler Plus is a strategy/simulation game, sequel to the 1982 TRS-80 release 'Supreme Ruler'. The player takes the role of Supreme Ruler of a fictional region, and must lead their region to victory against up to eight other players (human or AI). The player must contend with their economy, taxation, civilian health and happiness, loans, industries, and their military.

Players quickly realize that they must prioritize and balance the demands on their resources, otherwise their region will either collapse from within, or be attacked by its neighbors. In the end, victory is gained through dominating and conquering the other regions.

Up to 9 players via hotseat multiplayer.

sample_screenshots.caption: Setting parms for how the computer will play
Market values of change for many items
First round results H1-5 human countries and C1-4 computer countries

title: Supreme Ruler Plus

description:
Conquest of Chesterwoode is a turn-based wargame from Adventure International for 2-4 players. Your ancestors journeyed into the dark Forest of Chesterwoode, facing dreadful basilisks, worgs, a wurm, and more. Eventually civilization was established, and the land divided into 63 provinces, in a convenient hex-shaped grid. Then crops failed, there were food riots, and robbers appeared. Tyrants built fortresses to protect themselves from one another.

Now centuries later, as the descendants of those ancients, you want to unite the provinces. To do so however, you must fight, until only one leader remains. Only then will the serfs be freed from their servitude and peace and prosperity come again.

Gameplay is similar to typical board wargames with hex squares, but being on the computer, the rules can be far more complex and realistic than in a board game. At least 2 human players are required.
title: Conquest of Chesterwoode

description: Essentially the first home computer version of the Atari coin-op game Battlezone, Armored Patrol is a 3-D tank battle simulation. Your perspective is from inside your tank looking out at an alien landscape. Your mission is to find and destroy enemy tanks and robots before they destroy you. The terrain is filled with buildings behind which both you and the enemy tanks can hide. Score points by hitting the enemy tank before it shoots you and watch out for robots that can drain your tank of energy.

sample_screenshots.caption: This opponent has been shooting at me, better return fire quickly!
Tank preparing to fire, I might want to fire first...

title: Armored Patrol

alternate_titles.title: Haunted House: A Thrill-Packed Game of Mystery and Adventure For Your 4K Level I or II TRS-80 Microcomputer

description:
Generations have passed since the family mysteriously disappeared and the house has been vacant for decades now. Its two story image shows years of neglect, visible only from the narrow, winding road that has been distorted by vegetation from the surrounding forest. Your goal once you enter the house is to find the escape from the Haunted House.

Haunted House is an early tape-based text adventure. It has a standard two-word parser, such as 'Get Key' or 'Kill Ghost', to play the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Enter the second story... half way home.
Oh boy! Now you've done it.  How are you going to get back out?
I Know! It got me in the house maybe it can get me out!

title: Haunted House

description:
Two BASIC games on opposite sides of the same cassette:

In Backgammon two players face off. Games are played singly, with no overall score or doubling die. Input during gameplay is numeric, in choosing from a short menu of choices and in indicating which pieces to move. The rules are enforced, but not explained.

Blackjack pits one or two players against the computer as dealer. One or two decks can be used, and the cards played since last shuffle can be reviewed briefly each turn. Players can double, and they have the option of buying insurance against a dealer blackjack. Bets, as well as debt, are virtually unlimited.

sample_screenshots.caption: Blackjack Game start - number of players and decks plus player name

title: Backgammon/Blackjack

description:
Protect the galaxy against the hated and feared Jovians. You are in command of the USS Hephaestus in this space action game. You will have to manage your energy resources carefully so that you don't run out and get stranded in space. Keep close watch for any available space stations, while managing energy levels and weapons, and responding to Jovian attacks.

This game requires quick decisions on your part, as all action is in real-time. While the clock on your screen is running, energy will be consumed and Jovian ships in your sector of space will change position.

There are 10 levels of difficulty, which also changes the speed of the Jovians' attack.
title: Invasion Force

description:
The problem: years of launching spy satellites have filled the sky so much that plane travel is limited to Wednesdays -- every other Wednesday, in fact.

The solution: your reflexes, marksmanship, and a big cannon. Shoot as many "spy saucers" out of the sky as you can, in a limited time and as accurately as possible. At the bottom center of the screen is the cannon, which you can angle in five different positions. Some saucers are worth more than others, and on rare occasions you get a shot at one which will destroy all the others if you hit it. Go light on the trigger: missiles are expensive, which means you lose points for misses, not to mention saucers which get away.

sample_screenshots.caption: Fire! Attempting to hit a flying saucer...

title: Flying Saucers

description:
Paddle Pinball is a pinball game without flippers, but with a single paddle which you can move back and forth across the bottom of the screen. All the elements of pinball are here, with bumpers, pins, pockets, beeps, a siren, and even music. The paddle can be moved at two different speeds and can hit the ball harder when gravity has robbed the ball of momentum.

Up to three players can split the credits and take turns playing, with more credits available at point thresholds. A random match point which is awarded at the end might get you another credit.

The game also features a graphical editor, allowing you to move elements, even add pins, and save your new board.
title: Paddle Pinball

description:
As a scientist on the Pentagon's emergency call list, you're woken at 3 AM by a panicked general pleading for your assistance. Air Force investigators are not just at their wits' end, but have lost them entirely trying to figure out what caused a bright flash and now a glow in a Southwestern canyon. The private, who is driving the jeep which finally brings you to the outskirts of Purgatory, New Mexico, doesn't offer to wait.

Xenos is a text adventure that starts you at dawn of the same day on a desert highway, pockets empty and hoofing it toward the complete unknown. With resourcefulness, logic, and a text parser that can handle a few prepositions, who knows where you may end the day?

sample_screenshots.caption: Some useful items in a gas station

title: Xenos

description:
Your command is the Endever, your mission is the total destruction of the invading Jovian fleet, and your time is limited. In their bid to conquer the galaxy, the Jovians are attacking United Planet System bases; when no base remains, your mission ends in failure.

Scanners will help you find the Jovians and the bases, hyperdrive will get you there, and Masers and Triton Missiles will blast the Jovian ships into the ether. It's best to go in with deflectors up, because the game is real-time and the Jovians will start firing before you do. A full damage report is available, with the fastest repairs done at one of the bases. Combat is especially challenging because you must issue numeric commands, including direction and firepower, while listening to the Jovians blast away at you (sound effects driving home the urgency of your situation). Even outside of combat, the Jovian ships will move from quadrant to quadrant, and you may have to fight through magnetic storms or even around invisible black holes.

The action is shown via a map of your quadrant, including stars, ships and bases. The general status is directly below that, while scanning and damage reports are shown separately. Ten levels of play vary the number of enemy ships and the bases in jeopardy, to the point of making victory far from inevitable on the higher levels.
title: Space Warp

description:
As the Great Venicksia, legendary conjuror and Ghost Exterminator Extraordinaire, you may have finally met your match. This town is crawling with ghosts! Stepping off the train at the depot, your objective is walk to the haunted house and back, blasting as many ghosts as you can along the way. Your weapon is your own design, a "Ghost Blaster," capable of steady fire, though short, controlled bursts are the better option. The ghosts, of course, want you to panic. They're here to scare you to death, and to that end, each one that escapes will awaken the next, more dangerous ghost. When the thirteenth ghost appears, it's curtains for you.

This early first-person shooter presents you with a panoply of ghosts in classical forms drifting and darting across the detailed backdrop of a Western ghost town. As you shoot ghosts, you advance across the backdrop: bigger steps for more dangerous ghosts. Your passage is made more complicated by a laughing ghost whose head pops up briefly and must also be shot to prevent the ghost counter from ticking forward. Some help is provided by spiders, of whom the ghosts are afraid; shoot a spider and the ghost counter goes down, though then ghosts swarm back en masse. Your Ghost Blaster is represented by a movable sight on the screen, but it takes more than just a quick trigger finger to hit a ghost. You must lead your targets. This is the only sense of depth the game screen gives, except when that final ghost comes rushing out to get you.

Each pass through town is rewarded with a musical refrain, which changes from level to level. A successful round trip moves you up one level, which changes the background slightly and treats you to clever names like "Dead of Night" and "Good Mourning." There are bonus trips to be discovered and even a secret behind the appearance of spiders and the mysterious laughing head. If you beat all thirty-two levels, you are truly a Ghost Exterminator Extraordinaire.

sample_screenshots.caption: Different buildings scroll from right to left here is the Hotel
Quickly shoot them before they awaken more ghosts
The TOP TEN high scores are listed before a demo run is played
Game starts... the spiders and ghosts are everywhere
High score! You enter your name

title: 13 Ghosts

description:
Exploring a radioactive planet in the Betelgeuse sector, long desolate after the self-destruction of a legendary warlike race, you come upon a passageway leading underground. Much to your dismay, you discover that the aliens did not entirely self-destruct and that they are belligerent. Your escape is closed off; the only way to escape and warn Earth is to destroy the alien ships, find the hidden translocator, and zap to… another alien warbase.

Each maze-like warbase is protected by squads of three or four different alien ships with different capabilities. The Fighters just shoot at you, where the Annihilators, for instance, drop a ticking mine canister which wipes out the entire warbase. The translocator doesn't appear until you've destroyed the guards, and if you take too long with that, the Vexers arrive, making a beeline for your ship, walls notwithstanding.

You are far from helpless, however. Your ship can shoot in four directions and comes equipped with hyperdrive units, which are partially replenished by each translocator you nab. Hyperdrive zaps you to a random location in the warbase, a big help when Chasers are zeroing in on you. You can generate an antimatter field, too; that destroys all the walls, another life-saver when you're racing to the translocator with Vexers hot on your tail.

As you might expect, bonus ships are granted at point thresholds, and the warbases go on and on.

sample_screenshots.caption: Enemy guards become quicker and more numerous

title: Starquest

description:
The game Spook House – Toxic Dumpsite is a double feature adventure. Each adventure is unique and separate program for you to solve and explore. Both adventures also use an early form of interactive fiction with a graphics style interface. Each game also incorporates a real-time clock element of 30 minutes.

In Toxic Dumpsite a major problem has occurred at the nuclear waste disposal plant. You are trapped inside and must figure out how to prevent a nuclear disaster before containment systems fail. You have 30 minutes to complete the task and the clock is ticking.

The second adventure in this double feature is Spook House which you have been abducted and locked inside an abandoned carnival spook house. A bomb has been set for 30 minutes and you must figure out how to defuse the device and escape to freedom.

This graphical interactive fiction game uses a mixture of letter directions N,S,E,W and F,B,L,R (forward, back, left, right) for movement. You can also SAVEGAME your current location for restarting later. The command parser is a somewhat modified verb noun type.

sample_screenshots.caption: Sandy beach in a fun house... this is a big house
This isn't good... air vents are closed.
This room spins - doors rotate around the room

title: Spook House and Toxic Dumpsite

description:
You have befriended this phenom, this former commissary attendant of limited IQ but limitless energy and talent. Your task is to compose music and choreograph dance routines for him. Then sit back, watch the curtain rise at the next gig (Belvedere Theater, Oskowatcha, Washington), and enjoy the show.

This musical game translates two octaves of notes with sharps and flats to the computer keyboard, playing them as you compose. Rests are possible, but no half-notes or quarter-notes. For the dance routine, you can choose from eighteen different moves, varying in length and complexity from steps to spins, squats, and stomps. For inspiration, two routines are included, but you can save your own to create a vast repertoire for the demon. Each show raises the curtain on a hulking figure who dominates the stage, but adeptly -- indeed, enthusiastically -- matches every step you program, to the tune you composed.

sample_screenshots.caption: Options rate of speed and loop count

title: Dancing Demon

description: In Stellar Escort you are flying an escort fighter trying to clear the approaching aliens from your sector of deep space. You must avoid colliding with any of the six enemy ships types while dispatching them quickly. Additionally you must also manage your fuel and fire power to complete the level. Game play leverages both 2D and 3D elements with targets first appearing as small dots in the distance growing bigger when they move into range. The game supports sound effects along with keyboard or joystick control.

sample_screenshots.caption: Explosions invert the screen in fast flashes
Collided with a Crusher to my right

title: Stellar Escort

description:
Space Castle for the TRS-80 is a clone of the coin-op arcade game Star Castle. As in the original arcade game you control a ship firing projectiles at the central core on the screen protected by spinning rings.

In Cornsoft’s version you are trying to save the Andromeda Galaxy from the Space Castle and evil warlord Yugdab. You must exhibit skill in piloting your ship while destroying the defense rings, avoiding intelligent mines and space cannon. Only when the ring defenses are removed for a shot directly to the core will the Space Castle be destroyed. The game supports both keyboard and joystick input.

sample_screenshots.caption: Outer ring gone second ring almost gone intelligent mines chasing my ship
Outer ring about gone working on second ring

title: Space Castle

description:
In a sister game to Voyage of the Valkyrie, developer Leo B. Christopherson puts you back in the role of a buck private in the renowned Space Vikings. Norse folklore is again prominent, the plot borrowed from the Peer Gynt story. You must rescue the princess Anitra, held for ransom by the rogue Mountain Troll King, and as a parting gesture leave a bomb to destroy the entire Troldhjem Kingdom.

The catch is that Anitra won't come with you unless you charm her with jewelry, so you'll need to find some along the way. Also, keep an eye out for the scattered pieces of the bomb; all seven are necessary. These are hidden in the Norwegian Circle Maze you'll have to navigate to find the Hall of the Mountain King. Given that it comprises forty-one circles, each intersecting up to six others, you'll probably see most of it a few times over before arriving at your destination. Mapping your route is important, because while the actual rescue just requires reaching the hall, escaping means finding your way out before that bomb goes off.

As you might expect, there are also trolls in the Troll Kingdom: big ones with guns. Fortunately your little rail car which rides the tracks of the circle maze not only has a defense shield, but is quick enough to back out of any battle which gets a little too hot. Combat is a first-person view of the troll -- looking rather like Christopherson's Dancing Demon -- jumping back and forth and blasting at you, while you maneuver crosshairs to shoot him in the heart. This alternates with a status screen showing your address within the maze, rank, treasure and items collected, and body count. Bring back enough treasure and you could retire as the Prince Regent.

As the title implies, Edvard Grieg's Peer Gynt Suite provides brief musical interludes. Five levels of difficulty and seven variations on the fixed maze scale the challenge, which is single-player only. A sealed map is included in the booklet for those who become understandably desperate, and there's also a cheat key to start you at the climax scene.

sample_screenshots.caption: Animation walking from room to room

title: In the Hall of the Mountain King

description:
It's raining men. You have a basket.

An emergency in an office building is causing men to jump out the windows. Worst of all, they're in a terrible hurry and often jump two at a time from any of five floors, with little forewarning. In this arcade game you maneuver a large basket to catch them just before they hit the ground (with an audible splat, but no gore -- these are Model I/III graphics). The jumpers have a fair horizontal reach, too, so you have to hustle back and forth, and lead them just a bit. If you get in over your head, you can bounce one back up in the air, so you have time to catch someone else in between.

Misses rack up with gruesome speed in the sidebar of the single graphical screen, and five wraps it up, giving you time at last to examine your score. You'll probably want to keep your day job.

sample_screenshots.caption: Airbag deployed to bounce this jumper for another catch

title: Downpour

description:
In this side-scrolling bomber, you pilot the good ship Hercules, flying over Land Rovers which are firing missiles at you. Your mission is to bomb all the Land Rovers into oblivion so you can get on to the presumably easier part of attacking a small town. Fortunately for the town, there is an endless line of Land Rovers defending against your three ships. You're never going to see that town.

The Land Rovers are stationary and come five at a time, firing well-aimed missiles. You maneuver your ship over them -- up and down, slow and fast -- dropping just one bomb at a time. Your ship keeps cycling overhead until all five Rovers are gone; misses only use up fuel, which is limited, counts for points, and ticks downward more quickly with each round.

There's no bonus ships, difficulty levels, armor, or power-ups: just four arrow keys and three strikes until you're out. True to the genre, the game does give you an instruction screen and a score.

sample_screenshots.caption: Your ship above the targets below scrolling by with a missed shot going by your ship
You destroyed one of the Land Rovers below

title: Hercules

description:
It sounds peaceful, doesn't it? Lonely, even. Imagine just yourself on a desert isle in the middle of the ocean. Just you and the palm trees -- and the coconuts. This game is about you and the coconuts. The wind has picked up and the coconuts are falling. You must race across the island while dodging falling coconuts, which stream down from the top of the screen, exactly where you are trying to guide your 10-pixel avatar. If you're fast, you make it through, gain 100 points, and start again at the bottom. If you're unlucky, you meet a coconut at the very top, with no chance to dodge, or at the bottom just when you enter again in middle of the windstorm.

Five knocks on the head and the classic "Game Over". The single-screen layout is typical arcade as well, showing your score and "men" on the right side, with the graphical playing field on the left. Speed, however, is what the game showcases with its machine-language code. Of the four game speeds available, the slowest is a walk in the park, still challenging because your avatar is in no hurry, either. The fastest speed, though, caters to suicidal mania as pixels barely light before they are blanked and each trip up the screen takes about one second, unless you meet a coconut.

sample_screenshots.caption: Just got hit by a coconut
Main screen - almost to the top

title: Desert Isle

description:
"Based on the essence of science," as the game box declaims -- if not quite the reality of science -- Atom Splitting is a top-down shooting gallery in which you split atoms with carefully aimed electrons. Your atom smasher at the top of the screen can slide back and forth, but only kicks out one electron at a time, while atoms float side-to-side below.

Though atoms are replaced as they're split, they adopt an increasingly Brownian motion, changing speed and reversing direction. Direct hits become a matter not just of timing but good luck, and grazing hits don't even count. There aren't even high scores; this is nuclear physics, after all. Every game starts you off with 600 energy, while each electron shot uses 200 energy, and a split atom returns 300. You can ramp up your stored energy nicely at first, but as the increasingly Brownian motion begins to best your intuition, that energy drops to zero like quarters in an 80's arcade.
title: Atom Splitting

description:
Wandering, vicious bugs are on the loose. Your object is to trap them in seven boxes as they fall through cracks in a conveyor moving across the top of the screen. Unlike most arcade-style games of this era, Exterminator provides the player with nothing to move or aim. You must simply wait, fingers on seven keys -- one for each box -- estimating where the crawling bugs will meet a moving crack and fall through.

Getting the box number right, however, is not enough. The trap doors are open only for a second, so your key-presses must be timed within each bug's drop to be successful. Meanwhile, the cracks are catching more bugs which are dropping toward your closed traps. Naturally, the speed of the conveyor and the number of cracks increases with time. Let twenty-five escape and it's "Game Over," fifty points tallied for each one you successfully trapped.

Simple sound effects lend creepiness to the exercise, which centers around remembering which of your fingers will activate which trap door as you focus on the screen. There's no time for hunt-and-peck; at last those piano lessons will pay off!
title: Exterminator

description:
Mind Thrust has only a single-player mode.

There are two ways of winning the game: by removal of all opposing playing pieces, or by being the first to create a continuous chain of your pieces across the width of the board.

Play consists of alternate turns during which one may add a piece or attack abutting opposing pieces. The opponent may defend against an attack. The contest arises from correctly choosing which opposing pieces to attack or which of your pieces to defend. A successful defense is as important as a successful attack but is made more difficult by rules which make the allowable points of defense fewer than the available points of attack.

At the start of the game, the player may choose the side of the board and whether to begin first or let the computer do so. It is possible to switch sides at any point in a game and as many times as wished. The rules call it 'Legalized Cheating'.
title: Mind Thrust

description:
Delta Tau One is a fixed screen shoot 'em up that mostly resembles Galaxian. As in that game the player has to shoot down wave after wave of space aliens who occasionally make haphazard kamikaze attacks toward the player. The player's mission is to penetrate alien controlled sectors of space, by simply killing all the aliens, and thus allow the galactic fleet to take control of the area.

Space is divided into sectors that the player can jump between by using hyperwarp. After destroying all enemies in a sector the player automatically moves on to the next one. For each new sector the opposing alien fleet gets more powerful. At the first sector the aliens don't shoot, but in the later sectors they are armed with photon torpedoes and after sector four they fire at different speeds. When starting out the player has four ships and four units of hyperspace energy. More ships and energy is given for each 10,000 points scored and an extra ship is also given at the start of each sector. There are four kinds of enemies: fighter, interceptor, cruiser and flag ship, and each is worth a different amount of points.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the later sections the aliens start shooting
Aliens leaving their formation to attack

title: Delta Tau One

description: Mad Mines is a fixed screen shoot 'em up that includes elements from two other shooters for home computers: Ceiling Zero and Space Eggs. The screen is divided in two part by a force field. On the upper section mines move around until the player shoots them. Then an alien is launched from the mine which flies through the force field to the lower section where it attempts to crash into the player. The aliens are also able to drop bombs at the player. The player simply has to shoot them to prevent this from happening. Once all enemies have been cleared the force field is lowered and a new set of enemies arrives. There are four kinds of enemies and they move in different patterns and at different speed. The enemies of the fourth wave are special since they quickly move straight down towards the player. If they reach the bottom of the screen the player dies even if not directly hit. The player has three ships and an extra is awarded at 2000 points. The game can be played by one or two players.
title: Mad Mines

description: Meteor Mission is an arcade action game for two players. Unlike its sequel it is not a variant of Lunar Rescue although it has some minor similarities. The game takes place after a second big bang has occurred and the galaxy is full of stray meteors. Each player's job is to take control of a space ship and move it through the meteor belt to a space station and dock. The meteors move across the screen from left to right while the players' space ships are located at the bottom of the screen and the space stations at the top. The game is played with only two keys: up and down with no horizontal movement of the ship possible. If a player collides with a meteor, he or she gets to restart at the bottom. When reaching the space station one point is earned. A game goes on for three minutes and the player with the most points at the end will win. If the score is equal, the game will continue until one player has scored. Reaching a high score will lead to extra time. Before playing, a difficulty can be selected which affects the amount of meteors.

sample_screenshots.caption: Highest difficulty with lots of meteors

title: Meteor Mission

description: Meteor Mission 2 is unlike its predecessor a Lunar Rescue variant. The player controls a shuttle that has to be used to rescue six stranded astronauts from a planet. The game is viewed from the side with the player starting out from a space station at the top and the astronauts that have to be reached on the surface. To rescue them the player has to navigate through a field of asteroids and meteors and land on one of three platforms. The shuttle can be moved left and right and thrust is used to slow down its descent. After the player has successfully landed, an astronaut enters the shuttle which takes off again. To make it back to the space station, the player once again has to navigate through the meteors but this time he or she can use a laser to blast through them. The player also has to watch out for alien flagships that lurk behind meteors. Once all six astronauts have been rescued, the player gets bonus points and moves on to the next level.

sample_screenshots.caption: I don't really know what this is but I'm sure it should be avoided

title: Meteor Mission 2

description:
This simple ASCII-graphics TRS-80 game has you guiding a "Grand Prix" race car down a twisting racetrack that is filled with potholes. The object is to make it to the finish line of each racetrack after which you advance to the next difficulty level and must take on a more dangerous track. If you run off the road or hit one of the potholes you must start the race over again. The game is played from an overhead view with your car driving "down" the screen as the roadway and obstacles scroll up from the bottom of the screen. The controls allow you to steer left and right at two different rates - normal and fast. Difficulty is increased during gameplay by moving the position of your car gradually lower on the screen, giving you less time to react to curves and potholes.

The game offered rudimentary sound if you plugged the TRS-80 cassette cable into a speaker.
title: The Racetrack

description: Strike Force is a side scrolling shoot 'em up that is most similar to Defender but also has some similarities with Scramble. Like in Defender, the player can move the ship both left and right and has to protect a number of ground targets, here five cities. There is also a radar display that shows an overview with the locations of cities and enemies. In addition to shooting the aliens as they appear the player can also activate shields that offer protection to the cities. These however require energy which is only available in limited supply. Similarities with Scramble include a mountainous terrain that the player has to avoid crashing into and enemy ground targets that can be attacked. To be able to do so the player first has to collect an incendiary star shell that then can be dropped on the target.
title: Strike Force

description: Space Attack is a shoot 'em up that mixes elements from a number of popular arcade games of its time. The player's task is to defend a city which, like in Missile Command, occupies the bottom part of the screen. The city is being attacked by aliens unleashed by a feared warlord who aims to fully destroy it. The aliens attack from above and move around in patterns similar to fixed screen shoot 'em ups like Galaxian. They drop bombs on the buildings on the surface and the player has to shoot them down before they do so. Controlling the spaceship is similar to Asteroids, with a combination of thrust and rotation allowing it to move all over the screen and shoot in any direction. In addition to the regular fire, a super weapon can be used but it's limited to three uses. Another thing to watch out for is the fuel level of the ship. It's necessary to land and refill it before it runs out.
title: Space Attack

description: The Wild West lets the player take control of the famous outlaw Jesse James who has to escape a Texas Rangers ambush. The game is played from a top down perspective and Jesse can move and shoot in multiple directions. The game starts out in a house that is being attacked by two rangers. The walls of the building offer some protection but will ultimately break down by shots, both those from the player and those from the attackers. Once all enemies have been killed the game moves on to the next screen which features a different layout. Later activities in the game involve trying to rob a stolen payroll from a tribe of Indians, boarding a mail train and finally a heist at the Dodge City bank. Being hit leads to a lost life and when all three are gone, the game is over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Next stage out among the cacti

title: The Wild West

description: Rally is a variant of the arcade game Rally-X from Namco. The gameplay remains the same in this version, with the player controlling a race car through a maze, and the aim is to collect all the flags that are scattered around the map. At the same time, there are enemy cars that chase the player and in this variant there are as many as eight already in the first level. The player's car has limited fuel and if all flags aren't collected in time, the car will go slower and ultimately stop. If there is fuel left, the player will start with a fuel bonus in the next level. In addition to normal flags, there are also bonus flags that double the points earned. Like in the arcade game, it's possible to distract the enemy cars with the use of a smoke screen.
title: Rally

description: Laser Ball is similar to Pac-Man but has two major differences from the Namco game. For starters, the maze is empty when the game starts and instead of eating all the dots the objective is to drop dots so that the whole maze is completely covered by them. The other big difference is how the power pills (here called stimulators) work. Like in Pac-Man they allow the player (the laser ball) to go after the enemies (which are called destructoids) but instead of eating them it shoots lasers at them. Lasers are only available for a short while but there is no limit on how many shots can be made within that time. If the laser ball is touched by a destructoid during this time, the destructoid will piggyback on the ball and destroy it when the charge ends. To shake it off, the player has to turn a three- or four way intersection at a 90 degree angle.
title: Laser Ball

description: Learning Fun 1: Scurve Invaders is an educational game that combines space shooting with maths problem solving. The player controls a space ship down the bottom of the screen and has to shoot at the aliens (called scurves) that move back and forth above him. Unlike other shoot 'em ups aliens appear one at a time. Before shooting is possible the ship has to be loaded and this is done by solving a single maths problem. Once solved the player can shoot as much as he wants until the alien is hit. Points are awarded for each hit and removed for each miss. After one alien has been defeated another appears and the ship has to be loaded with another question. There is no way to die in the game but the game ends when the time runs out. Bonus time is earned when score reaches 5000.

sample_screenshots.caption: The female scurve looks like a chair

title: Learning Fun 1: Scurve Invaders

description: Attack Force is a Targ variant. As such it is a shoot 'em up that takes place in a grid-like maze where the player's ship starts out in the bottom right corner while eight alien ramships start out in the top row. As the game begins, the ramships will start chasing the player who has to shoot them to prevent getting caught. In addition to the ramships there are flagships that initially are located to the right, outside the playing field. From there they can zap the ramships and thereby turn them into clones of the player's ship. These have to be avoided since shooting them will lead to the player too getting killed. Once all ramships have been destroyed the flagships will enter the playing field and they have to be destroyed to progress to the next level. Flagships can hit the player with laser bolts from any position in the maze (and they never miss) but the player can take six such hits before being destroyed.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 2 looks the same but with higher scores (and tougher enemies)

title: Attack Force

description:
Computer Foreign Exchange is a conversion of Avalon Hill's own 1979 board game. It retains all the original rules and options and can be played by two to four players but does not feature any AI opponents. Each player takes control of a business with assets all around the world. The game world consists of 24 cities in nine countries which are evenly divided between the players. Each player has when starting out one sales office in each controlled city. The first phase of the game is a trading session where players can trade cities they control. Players should attempt to hold all cities within one country since that allows them to build manufacturing subsidiaries and thereby increase profits.

After the trading session, the players take turns planning their strategies for each fiscal year. There are several options that can be made: purchase sales offices or manufacturing subsidiaries, hedge foreign assets, borrow foreign currencies, use a cash management consulting service, sell sales offices or manufacturing subsidiaries, use a foreign exchange advisory service and list ownership and assets of each city. After the planning has been completed, players enter their jets and fly to the different cities. Players can control this by holding down the spacebar to fuel the jet and the longer it is held down, the longer it will fly. If players land in an opponent's city, they have to pay for it.

The game goes on until one player has reached a target amount of money. The target is based on which difficulty level (1-9) is chosen before the start of a game. The higher the difficulty, the more net worth is required to win.
title: Computer Foreign Exchange

description: Devil's Tower is a single screen shoot 'em up viewed from the side. The screen is split in two by a large mountain with the player being located on its left side and waves of alien attackers appearing on the right side. The aim of the game is simply to kill the aliens by sending projectiles over the mountain while at the same time avoiding their projectiles. The player can move left and right and shoot projectiles from four different angles. Additionally there is an option to drill into the mountain which then offers some protection. There are three kinds of enemies: attackers that launch projectiles from the ground, protectors which fly past and build force fields above the ground units and robot climbers which climb the mountain and attack from there. As the game goes on, the space available for movement shrinks which makes it harder to avoid enemy projectiles.

sample_screenshots.caption: As time goes on the available space decreases

title: Devil's Tower

description: Tribble Trap is a puzzle game where the player hunts a tribble, a furry little creature from the Star Trek universe. The game is played on a 7x7 grid where each square represents a galactic sector in deep space. The tribble, which is hidden, moves between the sectors and the player's task is to trap it without killing it. The only info given about it is its position the previous turn. For each turn the player can shoot out one of the sectors by entering its coordinates. That then prevents the tribble from moving to it. The game is won when all the sectors surrounding the tribble are destroyed since it then can't make any further moves. It is game over if the tribble is shot or if all available shots are used up.

sample_screenshots.caption: Killing the tribble leads to failure

title: Tribble Trap

description: Frog is a simple single screen action game where the player is in control of a frog that sits on a log in a pond. Around the frog there are numerous flies swarming around and the aim of the game is simply to eat all the flies. The frog can be moved left and right along the log and flies are eaten by sending out the tongue either to the left or right diagonally. The more the tongue is used the shorter it will get and hence the flies will be harder to catch. Once all flies have been caught, the player gets a score that is based on the number of them and how long it took.

sample_screenshots.caption: The tongue gets shorter towards the end

title: Frog

description:
The Great Race is a computer adaptation of the card game Mille Bornes that can be played by up to four players. The objective of the game is to drive 600 miles (from Boston to Washington) and first reach the finish line.

In each turn each player gets four cards of which they have to choose one to use or pass. There are three groups of cards: mileage (from 10 to 50 miles), revenge (stop, flat, empty and wreck) and repair (roll, spare, gas and fix). The mileage cards are used to move, the revenge cards are used to halt the movement of the opponents and the repair cards are used to counter the revenge cards. The cards that can be played depends on the player's condition. A mileage card can only be used when the condition is "roll" and a revenge card can only be used on an opponent that is rolling. Revenge cards changes the condition to "stop" and the player must then use the corresponding repair card to start rolling again. Cards are given randomly and if a player gets two of the same repair cards a protection will be given which gives immunity against the corresponding revenge card.

sample_screenshots.caption: White bars shows how far each player has driven
Wrecked players have to use the fix card to start rolling again
Getting two of the same repair cards gives protections
About to use a wreck card on an opponent

title: The Great Race

description:
Space Voyager is an alien invasion game, in the same genre as Space Invaders and the later Galaga.

However, the game play involved aliens who would come down in a fashion such that they moved from the left of the screen to the right, down a row and then from right to left until they would overcome the player.
title: Space Voyager

description:
Great Wave is a game in which space ships of various types would warp into space on the screen around the player's space ship, while the goal was to shoot the enemy ships as they were attacking.

The positioning of ships warping in varies greatly to challenge the reflexes of the gamer to quickly point and shoot. In the more advanced levels, the speed and number of alien ships flying in becomes more and more challenging.

But like Space Voyager and Space Quest, which comes later, Great Wave always provides level bonuses and rewards to motivate and keep the gamer moving ahead, until they would run out of lives (ships).
title: Great Wave

description:
Space Quest is the 3rd in a series of space warfare games developed in this arcade genre (Space Voyager, Great Wave and Space Quest).

The game play worked in such a manner that aliens would come down from the top one row at a time, but as a sequel game to Space Voyager, the formations of the aliens was different for every level, from the simple one row of aliens, to multiple rows that would move in both directions.

As each alien reached the edge of the screen, they would move down a row until they would overcome the gamer. Free ships could be earned as we as reward animations. For example, when 10,000 points were achieved, an alien space craft would land and bestow more points to the player.

sample_screenshots.caption: Bat-Like Creatures Come from Both Sides on Level 3

title: Space Quest

description: 5-Speed Racer is a top-down arcade racer. The goal is to race down the hill and get as many points as possible in the allotted time. As the title of the game suggests, there are five gear levels. The faster you go, the higher your score. Hitting the curb or driving in the grass will drop your speed to one and will decrease your score as long as you remain off-track.
title: 5-Speed Racer

description: Pentominoes is a puzzle game where the player has to place a number of shapes, each made up of five squares, on a board. There are twelve of these shapes and they all have to be placed on the board so that there is no space left. The game is played with the keyboard and the player enters the coordinates of the board to place the shapes. Each shape can be rotated or flipped before being placed. There are four different game boards (listed in order of difficulty): 6x10, 5x12, 4x15 and 3x20.
title: Pentominoes

description: Awari is a game in the Mancala family of board games. This digital adaptation is text based and allows one human player to compete against an AI opponent. The game board contains twelve holes in the ground that are arranged like an egg carton with six on each side. Each hole contains beans and the objective is to move the highest amount of beans to the player's home which is the hole furthest to the right. In each move the player picks up all beans from one hole and then drops one in each hole going counter-clockwise. Each hole is numbered and for each turn the player simply enters the hole that beans should be moved from.
title: Awari

description: Slalom is a downhill skiing game. There are three courses to choose from: slalom, giant slalom and downhill and the aim in all of them is simply to go down the slope in the shortest time while trying to manoeuvre through each gate. The game does however not keep track of whether the player goes through the gates or not which has to be determined by the player. The slope is seen from a top down perspective and the player simply uses two keys to turn left and right. Hitting a ski pole will lead to an accident and an early end to the race.
title: Slalom

description:
Lafayette Escadrille is a real time action, simulation and strategy game putting the player in control of World War I biplanes. You can select from 24 different aircraft including the classics such as German Fokker DR-1, French Spad or English Sopwith Camel. A variety of missions can be flown from defensive or offensive patrols, bombing missions, balloon busting and training flights. Mission duration is generally around 20-35 cycles (a cycle is the period it takes for the cursor in the upper right hand corner of the screen to blink on and off once). Using the paper battle map provided aids in course and target finding. The battle map is also simulated on screen with limited graphic and text symbols.

Game play is from a top down perspective with the player controlling the selected plane in X and Y grid. Keyboard entry uses unique keys allows common dogfight maneuvers such as Split-S or Immelmann turns. Each aircraft has differing rates of fuel consumption, ammo and bomb load capacities. After landing back at your aerodrome or crashing a score screen appears. The game has no option for mid-mission or in flight game saves.

sample_screenshots.caption: Shot down a Albatros D.V fighter patrol

title: Lafayette Escadrille

description: Owl Tree is a game similar to the electronic games Merlin's Magic Square and Lights Out. The screen shows a tree with nine positions that are filled by one bat and eight owls. The objective of the game is to shoot the bats and attract owls to all nine positions of the tree in the fewest moves. By shooting a bat it disappears and an owl takes its place. Its neighbours will also be scared away and replaced by their opposites. The position of the first bat can be chosen before starting the game (center, side, corner or random).

sample_screenshots.caption: Remember... you should not shoot the owls!

title: Owl Tree

description: Showdown is a shooting game similar to the arcade games Gun Fight and Boot Hill. Two gunslingers (human vs. human or human vs. computer) face each other in a duel. The players can move up and down along the sides of the screen, aim by raising or lowering the firing arm and then shoot at the enemy. Some cover is offered in the form of obstacles: trees, cacti and a moving wagon. Reloading is automatic but takes a few seconds. The game keeps track of scores but is endless and there are no winning conditions.
title: Showdown

description:
Zossed In Space follows the adventures of an unnamed spacecraft captain, impersonated by the player. There is no story, the goal is simply to survive a hundred sectors of space. Two alternate winning conditions are to either kill ten enemy ships or accumulate a hundred trade units.

In each sector, the ship appears on the bottom of the screen. It is directly controlled with four keys (left, right, up, down) to interact with respectively to avoid whatever is on screen. After reaching the top, the next sector begins. The most important aspect of survival is fuel management: the ship has five systems (weapons, propulsion, life support, defense and environment shields) which constantly use fuel. With a button press, the player enters command mode and can divide the main fuel reserve into the specific systems. This mode also serves as pause function.

Life support, environment shields and propulsion need to be over 0% at all times because otherwise the ship can't move anymore (propulsion) or instantly dies (the other two). Defense can theoretically be empty, but then encountering an enemy ships causes instant death. Weapons only need to be fueled for combat. Fuel is not only depleted over time, but also when encountering dangerous environments. For example, being hit by meteorites hurts the environmental shield fuel, the black whole drains life support or space junk the propulsion reserve.

After each screen is passed, the sector counter goes up by one. However, not all screens are dangerous. The player may also find traders (sell trade units for fuel), tankers (sell fuel for sectors) or free ports (allow to gamble for more trade units).
title: Zossed in Space

description:
Strip Concentration & Dice is an early adult-themed video game for the TRS-80 system.

Strip Concentration is a 2-player game, where players take turns flipping over a series of 30 cards on a large grid. Each card contains a piece of clothing, and there are also wildcards present. If a player picks up 2 matching clothing pieces, or has a wildcard, they will be directed to remove that piece of clothing from the opposing player. In Strip Dice, the players take turns throwing dice, which offer an array of explicit instructions to perform upon one's partner.
title: Strip Concentration & Dice

description: The Mean Craps Machine is an early craps game for the TRS-80 system. All betting occurs via text input. It is a gambling simulation for 1 - 8 players using Atlantic City Odds. The player can also compete against computer opponents, who get no advantage over human players. Players take turns placing bets, and rolling dice. The players compete until the house has collected all money.
title: The Mean Craps Machine

description:
The second in Adventure International's Kid Venture series, Kid Venture 2 features sound effects and an animated vignette based upon the poem A Visit from St. Nicholas by Clement Clarke Moore. Young readers can see St. Nicholas' midnight visit while reading the original poem.

Kid Venture 2 does not feature a quiz section as was seen in the original Kid Venture, but instead includes a matching game based upon the classic card game Concentration. Players must match character cards, including: hats, kangaroos, cars, and other images.

sample_screenshots.caption: My Wife and I Go to Bed

title: Kid Venture 2

description:
Demon Venture: Reign of the Red Dragon is an early TRS-80 RPG featuring black and white graphics.

At the beginning of each dungeon crawl, the player creates a party of 1 - 5 characters. Character races include: hobbit, dwarf, elf, and human. Starting classes include: warrior, magician, cleric, and thief. On character creation, player's statistics are randomly generated, and the player must purchase their starting equipment prior to entering the dungeon. Dungeon exploration is performed via an overhead view, with the player represented by an asterisk. Dungeon layout is randomized each adventure. The player randomly encounters chests and wandering monsters as they explore. The goal of the game is to descend to lower levels, and gather the eight pieces of the magic scepter. This will enrage the titular Red Dragon, and cause it to attack the player. Victory is achieved by slaying the fiend.

Gameplay is turn-based, but has a timed component. If a player sits idle, they will be attacked by wandering monsters. In combat, the player has a limited time to input combat commands, or they will not act during that round. The player is armed with throwing weapons, which must be aimed at creatures in combat using cross-hairs. Players will randomly encounter traps and chests, which can damage the player. When all available characters are deceased, it is game over.
title: Demon Venture: Reign of the Red Dragon

description:
The third in Adventure International's Kid Venture series, Kid Venture 3 features sound effects and an animated vignette based upon the children's song Old McDonald's Farm. Young readers can choose from 5 of 12 farm animals for each rendition of the song, and sing along with images on the screen.

Kid Venture 3 features a quiz section where children can match animals on the screen. There is also a demonstration mode, where the computer randomly chooses 5 of 12 animals, and cycles through the songs endlessly.
title: Kid Venture 3

description:
Capture is a 2-player arcade game for the TRS-80. Two separate players control an individual moving block in a limited field. As the block moves, they leave a tail behind, thus making the movable area continuously smaller. A player loses the game if they strike another white line. The goal is to try to box in the opponent to make them strike a white line. At the end of each game, players are awarded a point if they win.

The game was packaged with the memory game Symon.
title: Capture

description: Flippy is an early black and white computerized version of the board game Reversi or Othello. The program allows games for 2-player or 1-player versus the computer. The game features an 8 x 8 grid, numbered 1 - 64. The player manually types in the square they wish to move to, and the computer disallows any improper moves. The goal is to flip your pieces over the other player's piece, thus turning them the same color as yours. Ultimately, the player with the most pieces at the time all 64 grid pieces are filled wins the game.
title: Flippy

description:
The Mean Checkers Machine is an early black & white checkers game. The player uses text commands to move board pieces, and allows for 1-player versus computer and 2-player games.

The game uses American Standard Rules, and only legal moves are allowed. The game allows forced jump or optional jump modes. Other options include: The ability to take back a move, saving/loading games, the ability to set up your own board prior to playing, and the ability to switch pieces at any time. The game has 9 levels of artificial intelligence, but is set to difficulty level 3 on startup. At difficulty level 9, it can take 4 - 12 hours for original TRS-80 hardware to make a move.
title: The Mean Checkers Machine

description:
Starfighter is a black & white 3D space combat simulation, as well as a strategy game for the TRS-80. The game has 2 modes, a combat trainer and campaign mode.

The player plays as a mercenary pilot working for the Solar Galactic Authority, who is currently at war with the Petro Resource Conglomerate. The player is awarded credits for destroying enemy vessels, as well as rogue merchant ships and marauder Solar Galactic Authority vessels. The game is played from a first person point of view, and the player's ship can hyperdrive into different galactic zones to hunt enemy vessels. The accumulated credits can be used to facilitate ship repairs or purchase upgrades for their vessel at a landbase. The player can also refuel at these landbases and acquire bounties. If the player runs out of fuel, they need to request a tow to the nearest landbase at great expense.

The player starts off with the rank of New Pilot, and can advance to Ensign, Inspector, Captain, and finally Star Lord. The ultimate goal of the game is to claim the rank of Star Lord.

sample_screenshots.caption: Using Radar to Find Enemy Vessels

title: Starfighter

description:
Space Intruders is an early Space Invaders clone for the TRS-80.

The player controls a small ship at the bottom of the screen which can only move left and right. The ship fires vertically at invading aliens, which move left and right, while progressively speeding up and moving to the bottom of the screen. The aliens will fire selectively at the player, and if hit, their ship is destroyed. 3 blocks at the bottom of the screen provide a safe zone, but will slowly be destroyed by enemy and friendly fire. If all aliens are destroyed, the player advances to a more difficult wave. The player has 3 lives, and when all are lost it's game over.
title: Space Intruders

description:
Project Omega is an early black and white managerial simulation.

The year is 1990, and you are governor of one of Earth's first orbiting space colonies. The game is played by adjusting yearly settings for your colony's development, and each turn takes 1 year. Your job is to build industrial capacity off-world, and demonstrate the feasibility of orbiting production facilities, to reduce the pollution present on Earth. As governor, you must recruit workers for your factories, set salaries, construct living spaces and entertainment venues to keep them happy, and provide healthcare. You will need to expand your industrial capacities and build more housing to increase the size of your colony. Every year, you will need to pay for damage to your facilities from meteorite strikes.

Ultimately, you must pay off your initial 100 billion dollar amortization, finish construction of the orbiting colony, and recruit a sufficient population. Then, after building sufficient cash reserves, you will have demonstrated the feasibility of off-world colonization, and be victorious.

sample_screenshots.caption: Meteorite Damage from the Last Year

title: Project Omega

description: Delete This

sample_screenshots.caption: Asleep After a Late Night of Cards

title: Interactive Fiction: Local Call for Death

description:
Two Heads of the Coin is an early choose your own adventure style interactive fiction game. The game is black & white, and text based. At various plot points, the player is presented with several branching options for game play, with many incorrect choices leading to a player's death. The game uses an input format that encourages the character to respond in context, and attempts to pick out key elements to determine the player's true intent.

You play as a famed Victorian detective in the mould of Sherlock Holmes. Accompanied by your assistant Dr. Grimsby, you are met in the late evening by Mr. James Conway. Mr. Conway's wife Georgina has been missing for the last 2 weeks, and he has sought out your help. You must quiz Mr. Conway on the details of his wife's past, and the peculiarities of their marriage, to determine the true fate of Georgina.
title: Interactive Fiction: Two Heads of the Coin

description:
Z-Chess is an early black & white 1-player versus the computer chess game.

The player can play as black or white. The board is divided into 64 squares, and the player enters text commands to move pieces. Only legal moves are allowed. Moves are graphically displayed on the screen.
title: Z-Chess

description:
Bee Wary is an early black and white arcade game for the TRS-80.

You play as a bee who can move in 4 cardinal directions. On the bottom of the screen is a spider, who will attempt to move underneath the bee and eat it. If the bee gets too close, the spider can eat it. The goal is to try to sting the spider before it can eat you. The game keeps track of how many times the spider or the bee has won.
title: Bee Wary

description:
The Sledge of Rahmul and Merlin's Treasure is a collection of two text-based graphical adventures packaged together for the TRS-80.

In Merlin's Treasure, the goal is to locate 10 treasures hidden within a series of underground tunnels, and return safely to the surface. The tunnels are laid out in a grid-like pattern, and the player is able to look in all four directions at any time, allowing them to examine 4 parts of every square room for clues. The game only accepts 2-word responses, and a graphical display is presented to the character of what is in each room. The last 5 inputs are stored on the top right corner for the player to evaluate.

In The Sledge of Rahmul, the player enters a darkened cavern in search of the eponymous Sledge of Rahmul. As they enter, a deafening voice rings out, sealing the cavern behind them. Once again, the dungeon is arranged in a square grid, and the player must look in all 4 directions in each square room to gather clues. All commands are via text input, with a graphical display of the player's viewpoint. The player is awarded a score after exiting the dungeon, based upon the number of puzzles they have solved.

sample_screenshots.caption: The Sledge of Rahmul: I Escaped the Dungeon
The Sledge of Rahmul: Stuck Behind a Cracked Wall
The Sledge of Rahmul: Title Screen
Merlin's Treasure: Encountering a Stone Idol

title: The Sledge of Rahmul and Merlin's Treasure

description:
Sky Warrior is a black and white side-scrolling space shooter for the TRS-80.

The player controls a spaceship that can move in 4 cardinal directions. The ship can only fire in one direction, down and to the right. The player must fly through a tunnel which scrolls from the right, while avoiding striking the ceiling or the floor. The player must also avoid enemy rockets fired from the ground, while shooting fuel silos which help power their vessel.

The player has 3 spaceships, and if they are hit by enemy rockets or strike a wall, they lose a ship and must start over from the beginning of the level. If the player loses 3 ships, it is game over.
title: Sky Warrior

description:
Silver Flash Pinball 1 is a black and white pinball game for the TRS-80, which allows for 1 - 4 players.

The ball is launched from the top right of the screen. The game features a single pinball game with 4 flippers, shake control, and a tilt mechanism. The top score for all 4 players is displayed on the right of the screen. Each player gets 3 balls per game.
title: Silver Flash Pinball

description:
Backgammon is an early black and white game translation of the board game for the TRS-80.

Written in BASIC, it allows for only 1-player versus computer game play. The board is graphically displayed, and the player uses text input to place moves. The player is always represented by X. Only legal moves are allowed.
title: Backgammon

description:
Simutek Package One is a collection of 5 games made by Simutek, released by Adventure International.

Graphic Trek 2000 - A Star Trek simulation, where the player has a limited time frame to explore multiple different quadrants, collect resources, and destroy Klingon vessels.

Star Wars - A shooting game, where the player moves a cross hair to shoot incoming alien vessels. The player must first destroy 15 tie fighters, then the dreaded Darth Vader. Finally, they must fire a torpedo at the exhaust tube at the bottom of the screen, and quickly escape. Players are awarded point by how quickly they destroy enemy ships.

Space Target - Alien vessels move across the screen from left to right. The player fires a missile from the bottom center of the screen, and must direct it into the alien vessel. After an alien vessel is hit, the pilot parachutes to safety, and the player can shoot the escaping pilot for bonus points.

Invasion Worg - A resource management game, where the player must move their assault and defense forces between a series of 10 planets to repel the alien Worg invasion.

Saucers - Another shooting game, the player controls a cross hair, and attempts to shoot as many alien saucers they can while a counter reads from 100.

sample_screenshots.caption: Space Target: An Alien Parachutes to Safety
Star Wars: I'm a Bad Pilot

title: Simutek Package One

description:
In Tunnels of Fahad, you play as an explorer, attempting to loot silver and tanner leaves from the tunnels of the mummy Fahad. The mummy has every intent to make this as difficult as possible.

Game play is represented as a 3-ring track with a total of 71 dots of silver dispersed throughout. The player and mummy move in opposing directions. At breaks in the track, the player uses the arrow keys to move 1 or 2 lanes, while the mummy can move up to 1 lane. If the player comes in contact with the mummy, they lose a life. The goal is to always be in a different lane than the mummy while crossing. 1000 bonus points are awarded for collecting all pieces of silver in one life, and the track is reset each life. The player starts with 3 lives, and a bonus life is awarded at 2000 points. When all are lost, it's game over.
title: Tunnels of Fahad

description:
Slag is a text-based strategy game for the TRS-80 for 2 - 12 players.

Each player controls a nation, and no computer opponent is available. Playable nations include: U.S.A., Russia, India, Brazil, Israel, Atlantis, South Africa, Fenwick, Germany, France, Britain, and China. The goal is to improve your nation's industry to build bombers, submarines, ASW planes, ICBMs, and ABMs. You can also create spy networks to gather intelligence on your opponents. At the beginning of each turn, you select whether to increase industry or arms. You are given an option each turn to launch an attack to destroy enemy infrastructure of an opposing nation.

The goal is to destroy all competing nations, with only one remaining survivor.
title: Slag

description:
Back-40 is an early black and white translation of the board game for the TRS-80.

Written in machine code, it allows for only 1-player versus computer game play. The board is graphically displayed, and the player uses text input to place moves. The player is always represented by white, while the computer is striped. Only legal moves are allowed. Dice throws are displayed on the right hand side of the screen.
title: Back-40

description:
The Amazing Blackjack Machine is a black and white text-based program designed for the development, analysis, and study of blackjack.

Acting as a blackjack simulator, this game allows the player to set up a variety of blackjack situations, and simulate game play against custom computer opponents. The player can choose specific initial hands, betting strategies, and game play characteristics. For instance, the player can always start with two cards totaling 16, and can simulate 100 games where they hold and 100 games where they draw another card. They can then compare which strategy leads to optimized victory conditions.

The player can also set dealer characteristics, such as if a new deck of cards is drawn each game, or at what values the computer will hold or draw a new card to optimize strategies against such an opponent. Betting strategies can be optimized by simulating large or low bets with specific card combinations.

sample_screenshots.caption: Planning to Simulate a Number of Games

title: The Amazing Blackjack Machine

description:
The Black Hole is a three part shoot 'em up game that has some similarities to the arcade game Phoenix. The objective is to seek out and defeat the leader of the alien race the Dorfians who is hiding at the bottom of a black hole. The game controls the same in all sections with the player being able to move right and left, shoot and use a shield to block projectiles.

The first section involves getting through a long corridor without getting hit by any of the meteoroids flying past. This is made more difficult by the walls constantly moving towards the centre with little space left towards the end. In the second part the alien leader appears at the top of the screen. He is protected by a moving wall that has to be shot through. As time goes, the wall descends towards the player's position. The third section is similar to the mother ship stage in Phoenix. The player has to hit a target in the middle of the ship but first break down its underside. Once completed the game restarts at the first section.

sample_screenshots.caption: The walls moves closer to the bottom
Second section: Up against the alien leader
The space opens up at the end
This is as tight as it gets

title: The Black Hole

description:
Terror at Selachii Bay is a 1-player strategy game.

The player controls a boat and a crew, with the goal to hunt the shark which stalks Selachii Bay. The player must explore the bay, as displayed overhead, looking for the shark on their sonar. After locating the shark, the player must choose to fire a harpoon in 1 of the 4 cardinal directions, as well as choose from 4 separate depths. The combination required to hit the shark is determined by trial and error. The shark will intermittently change its location, and will move to a new place on the map whenever the player returns to the marina for supplies. If the shark is struck by 3 harpoons, it will die.

There are numerous dangers facing the captain and crew. Random storms will cause loss of supplies and crew. The player must avoid running aground or into shipwrecks, as the ship will rapidly take on water and sink. The player can also take damage from shark attacks, forcing the player to take time to repair their vessel at sea. Old mines dispersed through the bay require the player to remember an old man's password from the start of each game, or risk being blown apart.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Fought the Shark, and the Shark Won

title: Terror at Selachii Bay

description:
Concentration is a TRS-80 themed card-flipping memory game for 1 - 4 players.

The game consists of a 4 x 8 grid of cards, that mostly contain TRS-80 themed items, including: cassette, disk drive, 8-bit, Android Nim, and line printer. The goal is to match a similar card, to take those two cards off the table. In multiplayer games, the player who has the most pairs before all cards are matched is the winner.
title: Concentration

description:
Starclash is a 1–2 player text-based space-themed strategy game of conquest for the TRS-80.

Starclash allows 2-player or 1-player versus computer game play, and allows saving and restoring sessions in progress. Gameplay is turn based, and opponents take turns giving commands to their holdings. At the beginning of each game, a star system map with multiple different connecting hubs between them is created. The player and their opponent both start by controlling 1–2 systems, and must build their resources by colonizing adjacent systems. This allows the player to create a manufacturing base that allows them to construct ships to war with their opponent. The winner, is ultimately the player which manages to conquer all enemy territory.
title: Starclash

description:
Gridirion: A Microfootball Game is a 2-player American football simulation for the TRS-80.

Played from a top-down perspective, gameplay follows basic American football rules. There is no computer opponent available, and actions for both teams must be chosen by the players. During each play, both players choose a respective offensive or defensive play, and then the computer graphically displays the action. If a play is not chosen fast enough, the team will become confused and will perform errors. The players can not control a play in progress. At the end of each play, the current score is displayed. Each team can call 3 timeouts per game.
title: Gridiron: A Microfootball Game

description: Galaxy Invasion -Plus- is an updated version of Galaxy Invasion. It adds a few synthesized speech samples, the ability to pause the game, a changed high score screen and the option to turn off sound. However, the most important difference is that the screen flips vertically (i.e. the ship is now at the top of the screen and shoots downwards) after 50,000 points and flips back and forth for every 10,000 additional points.
title: Galaxy Invasion -Plus-

description:
Cosmic Fighter is a 1 or 2 player space themed arcade game for the TRS-80.

The player controls a small space fighter on the bottom of the screen, which can scroll horizontally. The ship is armed with a small laser which can fire vertically upwards. Waves of alien ships approach from the top of the screen, and then scroll out the bottom. These ships fire small laser shots vertically, while an alien mothership shoots large laser bolts directly at the player. The player has a limited fuel supply, and moving and firing uses up energy. Every several levels, a resupply ship appears on the screen. The player must align their ship with the docking port in order to receive more fuel, while avoiding or destroying the alien mothership. The player receives a new spaceship every 10,000 points. The player starts with 3 ships, and when all are lost, it's game over.
title: Cosmic Fighter

description:
Defense Command is a 1 or 2-player a space-themed arcade game for the TRS-80.

The player controls a small space fighter on the bottom of the screen, which can scroll horizontally. The ship is armed with a small laser which can fire vertically upwards. At the beginning of each game, a large spider-like creature distributes a number of fuel cells on the level, and the player's goal is to protect these from incoming aliens. The player must shoot aliens, while avoiding running into them. If an alien grasps a fuel cell, they will attempt to fly off with it to the top of the screen. If an alien carrying a fuel cell is shot, the cell falls to the ground. It will be destroyed, unless the player stays beneath it to catch it. The player starts with 3 lives, and loses a life when they are hit. The game is over when all fuel cells are lost, or the player loses all lives. A new life is awarded every 10,000 points.

sample_screenshots.caption: Aliens are Stealing my Fuel Cells

title: Defense Command

description:
Robot Attack is a 1 - 2 player space themed arcade game for the TRS-80.

A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away, robots from the planet Jidya attacked and overtook a space station from humans. The robots use this station to power their "Jidyan Land Kruisers", to scour the galaxy to eliminate humans. The human race is counting on you to invade the space station and conquer the robots. The codename for this mission is, “Robot Attack”.

The player controls a small character, who can fire in 8 directions. The player explores an endless number of single screen mazes, which always have exits on 4 sides and a door that closes behind the player when they enter. The player can eliminate all enemies in a room for bonus points when they leave. If the player stays on one screen too long, an invincible robot appears to hunt down the player. On early screens, robots do not fight back, but as the player clears more areas, enemy robots begin to return fire. The player or robots are destroyed if they touch walls. Robots can shoot and eliminate each other. The player starts with 5 lives, and when all are lost, it's game over. Goal is to maximize score.
title: Robot Attack

description:
Super Nova is a 1 or 2-player Asteroids clone for the TRS-80.

The player controls a small spaceship which can rotate left and right. The ship can move forwards, and has a cannon that can shoot forwards. On the screen are a number of asteroids which move about, and if they strike the player, the player is destroyed. Each asteroid that is shot breaks into two smaller pieces, and then two smaller pieces again if hit, finally being destroyed on the third hit. The player must also contend with spaceships which fire at the player. The initials of the game's authors float about, and can be shot for bonus points. The player starts with 3 lives, and when all are lost, it's game over. The goal is to maximize score.
title: Super Nova

description:
Weerd is a 1 or 2-player space-themed arcade game for the TRS-80.

The player controls a small spaceship which can move horizontally left and right, as well as fire vertically forwards. The goal is to blast hostile alien spaceships. The ship is armed with shields which can be temporarily deployed to block alien fire, but they only last for a short period and don't block alien vessels. The player combats an unending barrage of alien vessels with unique flight paths. Some craft will plummet towards the player, others carpet bomb from high above. Some alien vessels have multiple parts which split to attack the player. The player has 3 lives, and when all are lost it's game over. The goal is to maximize score.

sample_screenshots.caption: An Alien Splits to Attack Me

title: Weerd

description:
The Level II BASIC Reference Manual includes listings of various user programs, some of which are games.

  • Space-Ship Lander - A Lunar Lander variant in which the player must land a space ship on four different heavenly bodies (Earth, Moon, Mars and asteroid Vesta).
  • Target Practice - A simple shooting game in which the player must hit a moving target.
  • Ready-Aim-Fire - An extended version of the Bouncing Dot program in the User's Manual for Level 1. Allows for multiple players. A bouncing dot must be hit by typing in the right height to fire a missile at.
title: Level II BASIC Reference Manual (included games)

description:
The User's Manual for Level 1 includes listings of various user programs some of them are games.

  • Slowpoke - A reaction time test aimed at children.
  • The Wheel Of Fortune - Bet money on a number coming up on the wheel when it stops spinning.
  • Sorry - This program only draws the card of the Parker Brothers board game, the players still need to use a physical board to play the game.
  • Craps - A simulation of the classic dice game.
  • Castle Shot - Fire at a castle with a cannon.
title: User's Manual for Level 1 (included games)

description: According to the manual, you work for Scotland Yard and are trying to use a process of deduction to match 7 criminals to 4 crimes that were committed. In reality, it's basically a game of Mastermind.
title: Quick, Watson!

description: Laser Blazer is a basic shooting game with a first-person view. You use the arrow keys to move the targeting sights around and then fire when ready. You can also activate shields if needed. The enemies look like a mixture of Tie Fighters from Star Wars, Klingon cruisers from Star Trek, and basic flying saucers.
title: Laser Blazer

description: On first glance, Eureka looks similar to Boulder Dash. You dig in the ground for diamonds. However, there is more to it, as you need to sell the diamonds and also watch out for things like floods and falling off of your mining elevator. It is a strategy/action game where you try to decide whether to take what you have and run, or go after more and more wealth.
title: Eureka

description: This is a cut-down version of Adventureland designed for those new to text adventures. It had only 3 treasures to be collected and only a portion of the map available. The game was sold at the discounted price of $6.95 for a cassette or $9.95 for a disk.
title: Adventure #0: Special Sampler

description:
This is a collection of 4 games for the TRS-80 that are related to space:
